Column Comment.0: EQUIPMENT USE STATISTIC TYPE: Use statistics for equipment are widely variedin nature, depending on the type of equipment you are tracking. You may need totrack distance driven, distance drilled, total revolutions, total cost of operations etc.
Column Comment.1: ALIAS IDENTIFIER: A unique code that is used to distinguish this alias. Usually thiscolumn is included as part of the primary key for an alias table. Additional primary keycomponents are assigned from the parent or owning table.
Column Comment.2: ABBREVIATION: A short, often codified version of the name or identifier. May alsobe called a code, or reference number in some systems.
Column Comment.3: ACTIVE INDICATOR: A Y/N flag indicating whether this row of data is currently eitheractive / valid (Y) or inactive / invalid (N).
Column Comment.4: ALIAS LONG NAME: The long or full name assigned to the alias
Column Comment.5: ALIAS REASON: The reason why the alias was created, such as governmentchange, assigned by application etc.
Column Comment.6: SHORT NAME: A short name given to an alias.
Column Comment.7: ALIAS TYPE: The type of alias, such as partner, historical, records etc.
Column Comment.8: AMENDED DATE: the date on which a name has been ammended. Often, this isused for official or legal changes to a name.
Column Comment.9: CREATED DATE: The date on which the alias was first created. This date maypreceed the ammendment date, in the event that the ammended date refers to aformal registration event.
Column Comment.10: EFFECTIVE DATE: The date that the data in this row first came into effect.
Column Comment.11: EXPIRY DATE: The date that the data in this row was no longer active or in effect.
Column Comment.12: LANGUAGE IDENTIFIER: The language of the alias.
Column Comment.13: ORIGINAL INDICATOR: A Y/N flag indicating that this alias is the original or firstidentifier assigned to the object.
Column Comment.14: ALIAS OWNER BUSINESS ASSOCIATE: unique identifier for the business associatewho owns this alias.
Column Comment.15: ROW_MANAGEMENT_GUID: This value may be used to provide a global uniqueidentifier for this row of data. Use of this column is not mandatory, but if used,optional PPDM NOT NULL and UNIQUE INDEX constraints provided in the datamodel DDL should be created.
Column Comment.16: PREFERRED INDICATOR: A Y/N flag indicating whether this alias is a preferredname or code.
Column Comment.17: REASON DESCRIPTION: A narrative explanation about the alias being used.
Column Comment.18: REMARK: Narrative remarks about this row of data.
Column Comment.19: SOURCE: The individual, company, state, or government agency designated as thesource of information for this row.
Column Comment.20: SOURCE DOCUMENT: References the document where this alias has been given.Documents may be published, internal references, journals etc.
Column Comment.21: STRUCK OFF DATE: Date on which the legal name was struck from corporateregistry and is no longer used.
Column Comment.22: SOFTWARE APPLICATION IDENTIFIER: The identifier for the application that ownsthis alias or code or that is used to apply the data in this row.
Column Comment.23: USE RULE: A narrative column that is used to describe the circumstances in whichthis alias is to be used.
Column Comment.24: ROW CHANGED BY: Application login id of the user who last changed the row.
Column Comment.25: ROW CHANGED DATE: System date of the last time the row was changed.
Column Comment.26: ROW CREATED BY: System user who created this row of data.
Column Comment.27: ROW CREATED DATE: Date that the row was created on.
Column Comment.28: ROW_EFFECTIVE_DATE: A system assigned date that specified when a row of datais effective from a systems perspective. This may be the date that a row of data wasmade available to end users, for example.
Column Comment.29: ROW_EXPIRY_DATE: A system assigned date that specified when a row of data isno longer effective from a systems perspective. This may be the date that a row ofdata was no longer available to end users, for example.
Column Comment.30: PPDM ROW QUALILTY: A set of values indicating the quality of data in this row,usually with reference to the method or procedures used to load the data, althoughother types of quality reference are permitted.
